misconceptions.name: Solved a completely different problem (average acceleration instead of sum of even numbers)
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to compute average acceleration from v0, v1, and t instead of reading 5 integers and summing only the even ones. This indicates a misunderstanding or misreading of the original problem requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: I need to write a program that reads v0, v1, and t and prints the average acceleration (v1 - v0) / t.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read exactly 5 integers from the user, use a loop to process these inputs, check each number to see if it is even (n % 2 == 0), accumulate the sum of the even numbers only, and then print that sum.
symptoms: Prompts the user for v0, v1, and t instead of 5 integers.
Reads only 3 numbers instead of 5.
No loop is used to process multiple inputs.
No conditional check for even numbers is present.
Final output prints average acceleration rather than the sum of even integers.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student likely reused code or a mental model from a different physics-related problem and did not align their solution with the specific requirements of this assignment.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and restate it in your own words. Then design the program structure around those requirements: (1) read 5 integers, ideally using a loop; (2) for each integer, check if it is even using n % 2 == 0; (3) if even, add it to a running sum; (4) after processing all 5 numbers, print the sum of the even numbers.
related_concepts: Mapping problem requirements to program structure
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the program (variable names, prompt text, formula, and printed message) refers to average acceleration and does not mention reading 5 integers, even numbers, or summation, which clearly conflicts with the assignment description.

evidence.note: Code reads v0, v1, and t and computes averageAcceleration, which is unrelated to the requirement of reading 5 integers and summing only the even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Complete Misinterpretation of Assignment Goal
misconceptions.description: The student has submitted code designed to calculate average acceleration, which is a completely different problem from the required task of finding the sum of even numbers from a series of inputs.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe the assignment required calculating acceleration, or they submitted the incorrect file for this question.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment required reading 5 integers, iterating through them, checking for even numbers using the modulo operator (%), and accumulating the sum of those even numbers.
symptoms: Code calculates average acceleration: (v1 - v0) / t
Variable names are kinematic quantities (v0, v1, t)
Output message relates to acceleration, not sum of even numbers
Required core logic (loop, modulo/parity check, accumulator) is missing
misconceptions.root_cause: The student fundamentally misunderstood or misread the problem description, or they accidentally submitted a solution for a different problem entirely.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully reread the assignment prompt: 'Write a program that reads 5 integers from the user and prints the sum of only the even numbers.' Focus on implementing a loop structure and the remainder operator (%) to check for evenness.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code solves a different, unrelated physics problem (average acceleration) and contains none of the required elements of the original assignment.

evidence.note: The main method executes logic for calculating and printing average acceleration, not the sum of even numbers.
This function clearly implements the acceleration formula, confirming the incorrect task was addressed.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect Number and Type of Inputs
misconceptions.description: The required task asked for 5 integers, but the student's code reads only 3 inputs, and defines them as floating-point numbers (`double`) instead of integers (`int`).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the required inputs are three double precision floating-point numbers (v0, v1, t).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment required reading 5 distinct integers.
symptoms: Uses `double` data type for inputs
Only calls input methods three times
misconceptions.root_cause: Stemming from the primary misconception (wrong problem solved), the input requirements were defined incorrectly.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Use `input.nextInt()` to read integers and ensure the process runs 5 times, possibly within a loop.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Code explicitly uses `double` and sequentially reads only three values.

evidence.note: Only three inputs are read, and they are stored as doubles (v0, v1, t) instead of reading 5 integers.

misconceptions.name: Solving wrong problem
misconceptions.description: The student has written a solution for a completely different problem (calculating average acceleration from physics) instead of the assigned problem (sum of even numbers from 5 integers).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they are solving a physics problem about acceleration (a = (v1 - v0) / t) rather than the assigned integer processing problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading 5 integers, checking which are even (n % 2 == 0), and summing only those even numbers.
symptoms: Program reads only 3 values (v0, v1, t) instead of 5 integers
Uses double precision floating-point numbers instead of integers
Calculates acceleration using physics formula instead of filtering/summing even numbers
Output shows acceleration instead of sum of even numbers
misconceptions.root_cause: Complete misunderstanding of the problem statement. The student may have confused this assignment with a different one or failed to read the problem requirements carefully.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully. The task is to: 1) Read 5 integers, 2) Check if each is even using (n % 2 == 0), 3) Sum only the even ones, 4) Print the result. Start over with the correct problem in mind.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Near certainty - the submitted code solves a completely different problem from what was assigned. The assignment explicitly asks for sum of even numbers from 5 integers, but the code computes physics acceleration from 3 floating-point values.

evidence.note: Reads 3 floating-point values (v0, v1, t) instead of 5 integers as required
Computes acceleration using physics formula (v1-v0)/t instead of summing even numbers
Outputs acceleration result instead of sum of even numbers
Implements physics acceleration formula (v1-v0)/t which is not relevant to the sum of even numbers problem

misconceptions.name: Misinterpreting the problem requirements: solved a different physics problem instead of summing even integers
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to compute average acceleration from initial velocity, final velocity, and time instead of writing a program that reads 5 integers and outputs the sum of the even ones. This indicates a misunderstanding or disregard of the actual problem statement and required behavior.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that reads v0, v1, and t as doubles and computes the average acceleration ( (v1 - v0) / t ), and printing 'The average acceleration is ...' satisfies this question.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this question, the program must specifically read 5 integers from the user, check which of these are even using a condition like `if (n % 2 == 0)`, accumulate the sum of only the even numbers, and print `Sum of even numbers: <sum>`.
symptoms: Program prompt asks for 'Enter v0, v1, and t:' instead of 'Enter 5 integers:'
The code reads three `double` values instead of five integers
The core computation is `(v1 - v0) / t` rather than summing even integers
Output message is 'The average acceleration is ...' rather than 'Sum of even numbers: ...'
No use of modulus operator `%` or any check for even numbers
misconceptions.root_cause: The student likely reused or wrote code for a different textbook/example problem (average acceleration) without aligning it to the current specification, showing a misunderstanding of or inattention to the given requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully before coding and restate it in your own words. Identify the exact inputs, the required processing steps (loop over 5 integers, check `n % 2 == 0`, accumulate a sum), and the expected output format. Then design your code directly around these requirements instead of adapting unrelated examples.
related_concepts: Using loops to process a fixed number of values
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: All core elements of the submitted program (inputs, computation, output text) correspond to an average-acceleration problem and do not align at all with the specified task of summing even numbers from 5 integers.

evidence.note: The code reads three doubles (v0, v1, t) and computes average acceleration, printing 'The average acceleration is ...' instead of reading 5 integers and summing even numbers.
The helper method encapsulates a physics formula `(v1 - v0) / t`, which is unrelated to the required sum-of-even-integers task.

misconceptions.name: Fundamental Misinterpretation of Problem Requirements
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a solution for a different problem (calculating average acceleration) instead of the requested task (calculating the sum of five even numbers). This indicates a critical misunderstanding or failure to read the problem statement.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the required task was to calculate average acceleration given initial velocity (v0), final velocity (v1), and time (t).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The requested task was to read 5 integers and compute the sum of only the even numbers among them.
symptoms: Code solves a physics problem (acceleration) instead of an arithmetic/looping problem (sum of evens)
Reads 3 floating-point numbers instead of 5 integers
Uses variables v0, v1, and t, which are irrelevant to the assigned task.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misreading the assignment prompt, possibly submitting code for a completely different lab or homework problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Always double-check the assignment prompt to ensure the submitted code addresses the correct problem parameters, input types, required computations, and desired output format.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code structure, variable names (v0, v1, t), method names (computeAverageAcceleration), and output statement ('The average acceleration is...') all confirm this is a solution for a different problem, not the requested Q1.

evidence.note: The main method executes logic for calculating average acceleration, not the sum of even numbers.
This function clearly computes acceleration, which is irrelevant to summing even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect Data Type Usage for Inputs
misconceptions.description: The student reads floating-point numbers (`double`) instead of the required integers (`int`), which is a specific error derived from solving the wrong problem, but highlights incorrect type usage.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student is reading physics variables (velocities and time), which are typically handled as doubles, as opposed to the integers required by the actual question.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The required input for Q1 was 5 integer values.
symptoms: The use of `double` variables (`v0`, `v1`, `t`) and `nextDouble()` calls.
misconceptions.root_cause: Solving the wrong problem (acceleration calculation typically involves floating-point numbers).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Pay attention to whether the problem specifies integer or floating-point input. Use `int` and `nextInt()` for counting or whole number arithmetic, and `double` for precision-sensitive calculations like average speed or acceleration.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: All input variables are explicitly declared as `double` and read using `nextDouble()` methods.

evidence.note: Variables are declared as doubles and read using nextDouble(), instead of using integers and nextInt().

misconceptions.task: All tasks - entire solution is incorrect
misconceptions.name: Complete Problem Misinterpretation
misconceptions.description: The student solved an entirely different problem (acceleration calculation) instead of the assigned problem (sum of even numbers from 5 input integers).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe the assignment is about calculating average acceleration given initial velocity, final velocity, and time.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading 5 integers, filtering for even numbers, and printing their sum.
symptoms: Program reads 3 doubles instead of 5 integers
No loop to process multiple inputs
No even/odd filtering logic
Output is acceleration value, not sum of even numbers
Sample run is completely different from expected output
misconceptions.root_cause: Student did not carefully read or understand the problem statement before beginning to code. The student may have confused this with a different assignment or exercise.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Before coding, re-read the problem statement carefully. Create a simple test case: input [3, 8, 2, 7, 4] should output 'Sum of even numbers: 14'. Plan the solution step-by-step: (1) Read 5 integers in a loop, (2) Check if each is even, (3) Add to running sum, (4) Print result.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The student's code solves a physics problem with no overlap with the assignment. This is unambiguously solving the wrong problem.

evidence.note: The entire program is solving a physics acceleration problem with 3 input variables, not the assigned problem of summing 5 input integers.
Implements physics formula instead of even number filtering and summation logic.
